The direct synthesis of methyl methacrylate from isobutene is of great importance in the chemical industry. The direct oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid is one of the key steps, but the selectivity of methacrylic acid is low in the products of one-step oxidation of isobutylene. The efficient one-step oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid was achieved by preparing a Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV two-component composite catalyst combining asymmetric lattice oxygen with appropriate acidic heteropolyacid catalysts. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, FT-IR, BET, SEM, and others to analyze its structural properties, dimensional characteristics, and more. Results indicated that the composite catalyst accelerated the crystallization rate, with Ce enhancing the oxidation of the active molybdenum species and promoting oxygen activation to form lattice oxygen, thereby improving the oxidation of isobutylene. The heteropoly acids increased the percentage of medium strong acidic sites, enhancing the selectivity of methacrylic acid. Under optimized conditions, with an atmosphere to isobutylene molar feed ratio of ≥25:1 and a temperature of 400 °C, the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst achieved a remarkable 91 % conversion of isobutylene with a 70 % selectivity towards methacrylic acid. The catalyst shows promise for practical applications in the one-step oxidation of isobutylene to produce methacrylic acid, providing a suitable solution to the problem of isobutylene overcapacity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methacrylic acid Isobutene Selective oxidation Multicomponent metal oxide catalyst Heteropolyacid Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Isobutylene (IB) is a crucial ingredient in low-carbon olefins and serves as a significant organic chemical raw material. The main methods for the production of isobutylene include MTBE catalytic cracking units, steam cracking units for the separation of the C4 fraction as a by-product, and others [1,2]. MTBE is mainly used as a gasoline additive, and its demand has decreased sharply due to the national "two-carbon" target. Therefore, the catalytic oxidation of isobutylene to produce methyl methacrylate (MMA) has become a promising solution to address the issue of isobutylene overcapacity. MMA is a chemical monomer predominantly used in the production of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) [3]. In recent years, due to the rapid growth in demand for high-quality PMMA. It has triggered an increase in the demand for MMA, and the domestic MMA production capacity has grown significantly. In the process of MMA production, direct catalytic oxidation of isobutylene to produce isobutylene (MAA) is the most critical route, which has the advantages of high yield, green and cost-effective. The preparation of methacrylic acid by oxidation of IB involves two main steps: IB is converted to methacrolein (MAL), and then MAL is further oxidized to MAA [4]. However, it is difficult to realize the conversion in one step due to the different kinetics of the two reactions. Generally, MAA is a byproduct of MAL with a maximum yield of about 26 %. According to literature studies, lattice oxygen is the active site for the oxidation of IB to MAL based on the Mars-van Krevelen (MVK) mechanism [5–7], while acidic sites act as the active centers for the oxidation of MAL to MAA [8]. Therefore, the combination of active lattice oxygen and appropriate surface acidity shows promise in enabling one-step conversion from IB to MAA [9]. The amount and distribution of lattice oxygen in Mo-Bi metal complex oxide catalysts would directly impact the catalytic activity, and the main role of the molybdenum-bismuth system is to strengthen the oxidation ability, while the addition of cerium can increase the heat resistance and stability of the catalyst, then the addition of alkali metals can inhibit the deep oxidation of isobutylene [10–12]. Currently, most new Mo-Bi composite oxide catalysts are composed of elements like Mo, Bi, Fe, Na, K and Co, with additives like Ni and W. These catalysts can contain up to 4 or more different metal elements [10,13–15]. Wang et al. [14] added a smidgen amount of Ni to Mo-Bi composite oxide catalysts, and when Ni was added to the catalysts in the form of nickel molybdate, they believed that it could enhance the pore volume of the catalysts and the rate of migration of lattice oxygen, which could improve the selectivity of MAL. Udalova et al. [16] using Co-Mo-Bi-Fe-Sb-K-O catalysts found that Co and Fe could change the crystalline phase of the catalysts, thus enhancing the catalyst performance. Existing literature suggests that the addition of Ce on Mo-Bi-Fe-Co-K-O catalyst facilitates the generation of MAL molecules, which promotes the conversion of Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface, and the formation and valence change of Ce3+/Ce4+ and other redox pairs help to stimulate the lattice oxygen, accelerate the generation of oxygen vacancies, and increase the rate of transferring the oxygen from the bulk phase and thus increase the rate of reaction [17]. However, the precursor solution of Bismuth (Bi) known as bismuth nitrate is insoluble in water. The use of nitric acid as a solvent during preparation is not only harmful to the environment but also requires specialized equipment. As a result, researchers have turned to using vanadium (V) instead of bismuth for hydrocarbon oxidation to remove α-H [9]. It is generally believed that the doping low valent dopants in oxides can generate oxygen vacancies due to charge compensation effects [18,19], while improving oxygen activation ability. Therefore, introducing P element into the catalyst promotes electron transfer rate and accelerates the cycling rate in the system, which is often considered to be a key factor in promoting catalytic activity. Heteropoly acid catalysts exhibit a hierarchical structure, the Keggin structure, consisting of P, Mo, V, H, and O, are the primary structure of heteropolyacid catalysts [20,21]. Heteropolyacids based on Mo-V-P acids and their salts exhibit poor durability and thermal stability. By introducing various metal ions, the structure, acidity, and redox properties of these compounds can be modified [22]. Synergistic effects are generated through heteropolyanions, which in turn can improve the thermal stability and catalytic activity of the catalysts. To maintain the integrity of this structure while introducing other elements, a HPAV catalyst is initially synthesized. Subsequent modifications to the catalyst, such as the addition of K +, W6+, Cs+, Cu2+ and NH4+, are then made to enhance its secondary structure, allowing for a detailed study of their effects on catalyst structure and the oxidation of MAL to MAA [23–25]. Lee et al. [26] investigated the effect of Cs+ on P-Mo-V heteropolyacid catalysts by doping them with different amounts of Cs+, and found that the area of the catalysts was greatly increased when an appropriate amount of Cs+ acted as a counter-charging ion to replace a portion of the number of H atoms in the phosphomolybdic acid molecules, that the Cs+ ion was able to exert a certain inhibition on the migration of the V species in the heteropoly anion. Cao et al. [27] found that the introduction of NH4+ promoted the reduction of Mo and increased the number of acidic sites on the surface of the catalyst, thus also increasing the reactivity of the catalyst. Additionally, heteropolyacid catalysts were loaded onto SiO2, Cu-SiO2, MCM-41 and other carriers to improve the specific surface area and catalytic activity of the catalysts [28–31]. Mo-V-based mixed oxides with Keggin-type heteropolyacid exhibit unique properties in these two-stage catalytic selective oxidation reactions. In this work, Mo-V-P-Ce mixed oxides were combined with KCsWPAV heteropolyacid catalysts to prepare a novel two-component composite oxide catalyst for the one-step oxidation of IB to MAA, which improved the acidity and activity of the catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials O2 (21 %)/N2 (79 %) and i-C4H8 (1.01 %) were purchased from Qingdao Deyi Gas Co., Ltd. (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, CsOH·H2O, Na2WO4·2H2O, C4H6O (95 %), and C4H6O2 (98 %) were purchased from Shanghai Maclean Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. KOH and (NH4)H2PO4 were obtained from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. MoO3 was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. H3PO4 and C2H5OH were purchased from Yantai Sanhe Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and Tianjin Fuyu Fine Chemical Co., Ltd. NH4VO3 was purchased from Tianjin Fengchuan Chemical Reagent Technology Co., Ltd. V2O5 was purchased from Shanghai Shanpu Chemical Co., Ltd. The reagents were of analytical grade and used as received without further purification. All experiments were conducted using deionized water. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 The preparation of Mo-V-P-Ce catalyst In the preferred synthesis of mixed oxide catalysts, 6.180 g of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate [(NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O] and 1.755 g of ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) were mixed in a 100 mL three-neck flask at 80 °C. 50 mL of deionized water was added and the solution was stirred at a constant temperature for 30 min to form a homogeneous mixture. Then 0.173 g of ammonium dihydrogen phosphate [(NH4) H2PO4] was added at 80 °C. Finally, a solution of 0.217 g of cerium nitrate hexahydrate (CeN3O9·6H2O) in 5 mL of deionized water was added dropwise, and stirring was continued for 2 h. The resulting mixture was evaporated at 80 °C to form a solid residue, which was then dried in a constant-temperature drying oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The dried solid material was ground and calcined in a tube furnace at 600 °C in air for 4 h. After cooling, the solid was ground again, and the calcined solid powder obtained was the Mo-V-P-Ce catalyst. 2.2.2 The preparation of H4PMo11VO40 14.400 g of MoO3 and 0.825 g of V2O5 were weighed into a 500 mL three-necked flask, then 250 mL of deionized water was added and a magnetic stirring bar was inserted. The flask was placed in a constant temperature heated and stirred water bath, the side necks were sealed and attached a snake-shaped condenser tube to the middle neck, with the condenser tube connected to tap water. Turned on the heated and stirred, set the temperature to 80 °C. When the temperature reached 60 °C, 1.048 g of H3PO4 (diluted with 10 mL of deionized water), 85 % by mass, was pipetted into a three-necked flask. Then, the flask was sealed and refluxed with stirring for 5 h until an orange-red transparent solution was obtained. Afterwards, the solution was transferred to a beaker, mixed with the liquid from the cleaned three-necked flask, added to a magnet, stirred, and evaporated to dryness in a thermostatic water bath set at 80 °C and 450 rpm. Subsequently, the mixture was transferred to a thermostatic oven set at 80 °C and dried for 12 h. 2.2.3 The preparation of Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV dual component composite catalyst 5.000 g H4PMo11VO40 solid powder and 100 ml deionized water were added to a 250 ml beaker and stirred vigorously at 80 °C for 20 min. Then 0.470 g CsOH⋅H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of water, slowly added to the suspension and stirred for 10 min. Next, 0.093 g KOH and 0.924 g Na2WO4⋅2H2O were added to the above suspension by the same way as CsOH⋅H2O. After that, 5.000 g Mo-V-P-Ce catalyst was dissolved in the above yellow suspension, and stirred vigorously at 80 °C for 3 h until the solution was evaporated by stirring. The evaporated substance was dried overnight at 80 °C to obtain a yellow solid. The dried solid was ground using a ceramic mortar, and finally placed in a ceramic boat for calcination in a tube furnace. The calcination process involved heating at 350 °C for 5 h, with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, resulting in a two-component composite catalyst abbreviated as Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystal structure of the composite sample was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis (Rigaku, D-MAX, 2500/PC). The transmission infrared spectrum was obtained on Nicolet 8700 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Thermon 250XI X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with a monochromatic Al Ka (hν=1486.6 eV) excitation source. Additionally, the morphology and crystal size of the composite catalysts were captured using the SU8010 scanning electron microscope (SEM), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM-2100). The specific surface area (BET) of the catalyst was measured through nitrogen physical adsorption following the BET method using the Micromeritics Physisorption ASAP 2020. O2-TPD measurement was performed on using a Chem BET Pulsar TPD analyzer. NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) were performed by ChemStar TPX. The elements content of catalyst was quantitatively analyzed using an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) (Optima ICP 5300DV). 2.4 Catalyst activity test The tube furnace reactor utilized in the isobutylene oxidation experiment was custom-built by the laboratory. Initially, quartz cotton was placed into a reaction tube with an inner diameter of 10 mm and securely positioned. Subsequently, 1.0 g of catalyst was carefully weighed, loaded into the reaction tube, and evenly distributed by oscillation. Lastly, an equal amount of quartz cotton was added for stabilization. Isobutylene gas and air flowed out from the gas cylinder for the experiment. The two gases flowed through their respective mass flow meters, with the controller adjusted the flow meter to maintain a gas ratio of VAir: Vi-C4H8 = 10:1 for the production of a mixed reaction gas. Upon heated the catalyst to a suitable temperature under standard pressure, the reaction gas was directed into the reaction tube of the tube furnace reactor for catalytic oxidation. Subsequently, the gas passed through the reaction tube, where the product condensed and entered a collection bottle containing ethanol for further processing. Simultaneously, the gas components were collected in a gas sampling bag. After a 1-hour reaction, the products were sampled and analyzed using a gas chromatograph to examine both gas and liquid phase products at the outlet. To further analyze the products, ethanol solutions with varying concentrations of MAL and MAA were prepared. Gas chromatography was then utilized to measure the peak areas of these solutions. Standard curves for MAL and MAA were obtained by plotting concentration on the horizontal axis and peak areas on the vertical axis. The methodology for constructing the standard curve of gas IB remained consistent. Gas sampling bags were utilized for gathering gases with varying concentrations of i-C4H8/Air, while gas chromatography was employed to analyze the peak area of gases with different concentrations. The gas concentration was represented on the horizontal axis, while the peak area was depicted on the vertical axis, resulted in a well-correlated IB standard curve. The reaction device is shown in Fig. 1 . The evaluation performance indicators for this catalyst include the conversion rate of isobutylene, the selectivity of methacrylic acid, and the single-pass yield of methacrylic acid. Their definitions are as follows: Conversion of i-C4H8 = (moles of reacted i-C4H8/moles of raw material supplied i-C4H8) ×100 % Selectivity of MAL, MAA = (moles of MAL or MAA produced / moles of i-C4H8 consumed) ×100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Experimental result Table 1 showcased the catalytic performance outcomes of directly oxidizing MAA with IB. MAA is the major product, and the main by-products are methacrylaldehyde and carbon oxides. While the Mo-V-P-Ce catalyst by itself did not yield MAA, incorporating heteropolyacid components notably increased the selectivity towards MAA. Particularly, Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV demonstrated the highest activity and selectivity for MAA among the catalysts tested. It is noteworthy that neither Mo-V-P-Ce nor KCsWPAV individually produced MAA, highlighting the need to combine the two catalysts for MAA formation. Next, we optimized the ratio of Mo-V-P-Ce and KCsWPAV to improve the catalytic performance of Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV. The doping amounts of Mo-V-P-Ce and KCsWPAV had a large impact on the catalyst performance. The results showed that the best activity and selectivity of the catalyst for MAA was achieved when the ratio of Mo-V-P-Ce and KCsWPAV was 1/1. Incorporating Ce into the catalyst enhances its selectivity for MALs and MAAs. However, when the quantity of Ce added is minimal, it fails to exert a significant impact on the catalyst system. Conversely, an excessive amount of Ce can disrupt the balance of the catalyst's main active components, leading to a decrease in its activity. The content of Ce in the catalyst was optimized, and from Table 1, it can be seen that the selectivity of the catalyst for MAA increases and then decreases with the increase of Ce content, an optimal MAA selectivity of 70 % was achieved at a molar ratio of Mo: V: P: Ce = 7:3:0.3:0.075. Hence, the ideal ratio for the catalyst is Mo: V: P: Ce = 7:3:0.3:0.075. The prepared samples were compared with the relevant samples reported in the recent literature, as shown in Table 2 . From the table, it can be seen that Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV exhibited good catalytic activity. In addition, this work adopts a heteropolyacid catalyst and uses a green preparation process, which effectively increases the acidity of the catalyst, and achieving a MAA conversion of 70 % while achieving a conversion rate of 90 %. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The catalyst was initially characterized by XRD analysis. As shown in Fig. 2 the peaks observed at 2θ=18.26°, 21.54°, 24.94°, 27.3°, 33.24° and 33.84° are in line with the characteristic peaks of the (400), (001), (110), (002), (111) and (510) crystal planes of Mo6V9O40 in the orthogonal crystal system (PDF #84–1952), indicating the formation of a new material structure between Mo and V [34,35]. The structure of Mo6V9O40, as determined by powder neutron diffraction, indirectly suggests the presence of Mo-O-V interactions. Furthermore, X-ray diffraction analysis of both heteropolyacid catalysts and two-component composite catalysts revealed diffraction peaks at 2θ=10.56°, 19.9°, and 26.14°, which precisely match with the Keggin structured H4PMo11VO40 catalyst, providing further evidence of the stable heteropolyacid structure within the catalyst product [36]. Experimental evidence supporting the existence of Mo-O-V was sought through FT-IR analysis of the catalyst. Fig. 3 displays peaks at 967 cm−1 and 819 cm−1 attributed to Mo=O and Mo-O bonds, respectively. The peaks at 592 cm−1 were indicative of V-O-V bonds. The infrared spectroscopic analysis of dual component composite catalysts revealed four characteristic peaks in the range of 500–2000 cm−1, displaying typical IR absorption bands of the Keggin structure. These findings are in line with previous literature reports. Specifically, 1064 cm−1 corresponded to the P-Oa bond in the catalytic center, 967 cm−1 to the terminal Mo=Ot bond, and 870 cm−1 and 794 cm−1 to the Mo-Ob-Mo bridge oxygen bond and the intergroup Mo–Oc–Mo bridged oxygen bonds (Oa: the oxygen atom linked to the central P atom; Ob and Oc: denote the bridging oxygen atoms in the MoO6 octahedral cluster; Ot: the terminal oxygen atom) [37–39]. These findings indicated the stability of the heteropolyacid component in the catalyst's Keggin structure [40]. The absorption peaks at 1626 cm−1 and 3422 cm−1 were attributed to the stretching vibration of HO-H and OH. The synthesized KCsWPAV heteropolyacid catalyst and composite catalyst exhibit absorption peaks characteristic of Keggin type heteropolyacid, in summary, upon comparison with the XRD image of the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst in Fig. 2, the results align and mutually confirm each other. SEM characterization was conducted to analyze the changes in surface morphology of the samples upon the addition of different elements. Fig. 4 displays the SEM images of Mo-V-P-Ce, KCsWPAV, and Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV samples. A scale of 200 nm was chosen for size comparison. In Fig. 4a, the Mo-V-P-Ce sample appears in the form of slender strips or sheets, with relatively uniform sizes. Fig. 4b shows the KCsWPAV sample as cylindrical or spherical particles, with the addition of Mo-V-P-Ce resulting in irregular small pieces in Fig. 4c. The samples exhibited even dispersion with elongated, flaky, and spherical particles on the surface, suggesting that the dual component composite catalyst combines the performance characteristics of Mo-V based composite oxide catalyst and heteropoly acid catalyst. TEM and HRTEM images of the samples were obtained by transmission electron microscopy, as shown in Fig. 5 . The images reveal elongated and microsphere-like structures present in the sample, indicating that Mo-V-P-Ce and HPAV were successfully combined. The lattice structure of the composites can be observed in the HRTEM images (Fig. 5d). The lattice fringe of 0.122 nm and 0.148 nm were corresponding to (001) facet of Mo6V9O40 and (444) facet of HPAV respectively, indicating the existence of the two components. Additionally, Fig. 5b and c demonstrate the presence trace pore structures in the interior of KCsWPAV and Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV composite catalysts, aligning with the BET characterization results. Comparison with the SEM images of the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst in Fig. 4 shows consistent findings between the two, providing mutual confirmation of the results. The ICP-OES results were detected by an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry to quantify the elements of the catalyst. As shown in the Table 3 , the elemental ratio of Mo-V-P-Ce for the catalyst with optimum performance is 48.94: 10.49: 0.92: 0.79. Utilizing EDX spectroscopy allows for the rapid acquisition of information regarding the chemical composition of a sample, including element composition, distribution, and concentration. In Fig. 6 , the EDX spectra of Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV samples were presented, with each element distinguished by a different color. Analysis of the element content and distribution reveals that Mo and V have the highest concentrations, while P and Ce exhibit a more dispersed distribution, likely due to their lower quantities added during the preparation process. The EDX spectra of Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV confirmed the uniform distribution of all elements within the catalyst nanoparticles. In order to study the specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume of materials, N2 adsorption-desorption analysis can be utilized for sample characterization. The results of N2 adsorption-desorption characterization for Mo-V-P-Ce, KCsWPAV, HPAV, and Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV samples were presented in Fig. 7 . The specific surface area of the material was determined using the Brunauer Emmett Teller (BET) method, while the pore size was calculated using the Barrett Joyner Halenda (BJH) method. The pore volume of the material was calculated at a relative pressure (P/P0) of 0.99. The N2 adsorption-desorption results showed that a H3-type hysteresis loop was formed on the catalyst, indicating that capillary coalescence occurred on the catalyst. The hysteresis loop exhibited by the material does not reach adsorption saturation at relatively high pressures, a finding that aligns with observations from SEM and TEM images. According to the findings presented in Table 4 , the pore size of the material is approximately 3 nm, and the pore volume is around 0.03 cm3/g, this indicates that all pores within the material are in the mesoporous range. After modification with KCsWPAV, the specific surface area and pore volume of the composite catalysts were slightly increased. The increase of specific surface area implies that the reactive gases had a greater chance to come into contact with the catalyst as well as the catalyst exposes more active sites [41–43]. XPS was used to analyze the catalyst and investigate its elemental composition and valence state. Apply charge correction based on the C 1 s peak of environmental pollution C at 284.8 eV to ensure accuracy and eliminate potential errors. Fig. 8 indicates the measured spectra of Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV along with the detailed spectra of various elements. The spectrum in Fig. 8a confirms the presence of Mo, V, P, Ce, K, Cs, W, C, and O elements. As shown in the XPS fine spectrum of Mo 3d (Fig. 8b), two peaks were detected at binding energies of 232.6 eV and 235.75 eV, corresponding to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2, respectively. Following deconvolution, Mo6+ (232.85 eV) and Mo5+ (232.5 eV) species were distinguished. In the spectrum of V 2p shown in Fig. 8c, two peaks were detected at binding energies of 517.45 eV and 524.7 eV, corresponding to V 2p3/2 and V 2p1/2, respectively. Peak fitting analysis revealed that these peaks can be assigned to V5+ (517.43 eV) and V4+ (516.90 eV). As for P 2p in Fig. 8d, two peaks were observed near binding energies of 133.40 eV and 134.15 eV, respectively attributed to P 2p3/2 and P 2p1/2, indicating the presence of P5+. In Fig. 8e, two peaks were observed at 884.80 eV and 901.80 eV, corresponding to Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 in Ce, respectively. After deconvolution, Ce3+(884.85 eV) and Ce4+(901.66 eV) can be identified [44–46]. As for K 2p in Fig. 8f, two peaks corresponding to K 2p and K 2p3/2 were observed at 284.8 eV and 293.2 eV, indicating the presence of K +. In the fine spectrum of Cs 3d in Fig. 8g, two peaks were observed near the binding energies of 723.76 eV and 737.70 eV, respectively attributed to Cs 3d5/2 and Cs 3d3/2, indicating the presence of Cs+. As shown in the XPS fine spectrum of W 4f (Fig. 8h), two peaks were observed near binding energies of 37.45 eV and 35.3 eV, respectively belonging to W 4f7/2 and W 4f5/2. After deconvolution, W6+(37.39 eV) and metal W (35.34 eV) can be identified. In the O 1 s spectrum (Fig. 8i), three deconvolution peaks of O 1 s were observed. The binding energies of 531.9 eV, 530.95 eV, and 530.35 eV correspond to hydroxyl groups, oxygen vacancies, and lattice oxygen in water, respectively. The XPS characterization results from the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV samples showed that the appropriate release rate of lattice oxygen species would enhance the activity of O2 activation to oxygen vacancy species. Under the reaction conditions, the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst has a suitable activity for the conversion of oxygen vacancy species to lattice oxygen species and a fast migration rate of lattice oxygen species, which makes it capable of providing active lattice oxygen species for the oxidation of IB in a limited manner, easily replenishes the depleted lattice oxygen species, and contributes to the improvement of the selectivity in catalyzing the oxidation of IB to MAA, while under the reaction conditions. As depicted in Fig. 9 , O2-TPD analysis is employed to identify oxygen species present on the catalyst. It is commonly accepted that catalysts contain three distinct types of oxygen species. Previous studies indicate that the first type consists of physically adsorbed oxygen that desorbs at temperatures below 200 ℃, making it nearly undetectable. The second type comprises surface active oxygen species, which typically desorb within the temperature range of 200–600 °C [47,48]. The desorption analysis revealed two distinct peaks at 400–600 ℃. Peak 1, occurring at a lower temperature (430–530 ℃), is likely attributed to the desorption of surface oxygen deficient species. Peak 2 is located in the higher temperature range of 530–600 ℃ and belongs to the surface lattice oxygen species. The third desorption peak is above 600 ℃, denoted as peak 3, which belongs to the lattice oxygen in the catalyst body. For Mo-V based oxide catalysts, the desorption temperature of lattice oxygen is 663 ℃. The introduction of heteropolyacids causes a shift in the desorption temperature of this peak to lower temperatures. This suggests that the presence of heteropolyacid catalysts significantly helps to excite lattice oxygen and enhances the migration capability of surface-active oxygen species on the catalyst [10,49–51]. Then, the acidity of the catalyst was studied through NH3-TPD [52]. As shown in Fig. 10 , six peaks were obtained by deconvoluting the spectra of the split peaks. Peaks I and II correspond to weakly acidic sites, III and IV correspond to moderately acidic sites, and V and VI correspond to strongly acidic sites. By integrating each peak, the data in Table 5 are obtained, which shows that the Mo-V-P-Ce catalysts have the highest percentage of strong acid, while the Mo-V-P-Ce catalyst, after being modified with KCsWPAV catalyst, can be found to have a significant reduction in the number of strong acid sites. The number of strong acid sites in the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV composite catalyst is higher than the number of weak acid sites and strong acid sites. This catalyst increased the selectivity for MAA, aligning with findings from previous literature. 3.3 The reaction mechanism For the oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid, we know from some references that, Liu [9] combined with the results of XRD and IR, it is inferred that the presence of active center Mo6+-O-V5+ exists in the catalyst, which acts on the oxidation of MAL to MAA. Chansai [53] found that the H-D exchange possibly occurs on the bridging oxygen of Mo-O-Mo unit, where water is activated for the formation of MAA. It is worth pointing out that Cao [23] noted that the reaction pathway in the absence of water is similar to that in the presence of water the difference is that the hydrogen atom of MAL is extracted by the bridging oxygen (Mo-O-Mo) group and then recombined with the coordinated carboxylate (-OC(R)O-) type intermediates to form the MAA product. And Kanno [31] proposed that acidic sites are indispensable for selective formation of MAA. The reaction mechanism was inferred by combining the experimental data, the results of XRD, FT-IR and XPS spectra as shown in Eqs. (1)–(6), (□ represents lattice oxygen vacancies). (1) H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) 2 + O lattice 2 − → H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) C H 2 • + OH • (2) O lattice 2 − + H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) C H 2 • → □ + H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) CHO + H • (3) H • + OH • → H 2 O + □ (4) H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) CHO + 2 O lattice 2 − → H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) C ∥ O − O • + OH • (5) H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) C ∥ O − O • + OH • → H 2 C = C ( C H 3 ) C ∥ O − OH + □ + O lattice 2 − (6) O 2 + 2 □ + 4 e − → 2 O lattice 2 − It is deduced that a Mo-O-V structure exists in the catalyst. According to the reaction results, the synergy between Mo and V in the catalyst significantly enhances its catalytic activity. It is speculated that the reaction center is Mo6+-O-V5+ in Mo6V9O40, and Mo6V9O40 is known as an example of an active center in other reactions [9]. The reaction mechanism, illustrated in Fig. 11 involves initial adsorption between IB and the transition metal Mo, followed by removal of a hydrogen from α-CH3 in IB by the V = O double bond to generate a reaction intermediate CH2 C(CH3)-CH2•. This intermediate then interacts with the lattice oxygen of Mo6+-O-V5+. Subsequent nucleophilic attack occurs on the lattice oxygen in Mo, while one H is extracted from -CH2• and transferred to the Mo=O double bond. This process leads to the formation of CH2 C(CH3)-CHO from CH2 C(CH3)-CH2•, and the lattice oxygen combines with the extracted H to produce water. IB transfers electrons to Mo6+ in the catalyst through chemical adsorption. The Mo6+ then quickly transfers electrons to P5+, reducing it to P3+. Gas O2 adsorbed on P3+, the reduced metal is re-oxidized, the O2 seizes the electrons of P3+ to generate a new lattice oxygen(O2−) [19]. At the same time, the introduction of Ce element can increase the proportion of the active component Mo6+in the catalyst [18]. Generally speaking, the addition of Ce promotes the generation of defects and redox pairs of Ce3+/Ce4+ and Mo4+/Mo6+ [54], while weakening the metal oxygen bonds in the catalyst, and facilitates the reaction process of Eq. (6), enhancing the synergistic interactions between Ce and Mo species, thereby regulating the catalytic redox ability, oxygen storage ability, and oxygen migration rate in the selective oxidation of IB to generate MAL [55,56]. The catalytic reaction was conducted in a N2 atmosphere, and the products were collected and detected using gas chromatography. Even after the same reaction time, a small quantity of methacrolein was still generated, suggesting that the oxidation process from IB to methacrolein involved lattice oxygen. MALs molecules desorbed from the active site and adsorbed to the bridging oxygen HPA active site, the acidic protons on the end oxygen or bridge oxygen of the Keggin unit of the catalyst molecules activate MALs, accompanied by the opening of the C = O double bond in the MALs [57]. The activated MALs are oxidized to MAA by the bridging oxygen of the catalyst to form a carboxylate structure and desorbed to form MAA; simultaneously this is accompanied by chemical bond breaking and charge transfer of the bridging oxygens M-O and O-Mo, Mo6+is reduced to Mo5+. When O2 is introduced, the reduced Mo is oxidized back to Mo6+, and the corresponding bridging oxygen vibration peak slowly appears, returning to the molecular state with a complete Keggin structure, forming new active sites [58,59]. The introduction of K atoms leads to the formation of more pores inside the catalyst, while the addition of W increases the proportion of medium to strong acids in the catalyst, playing a crucial role in improving MAA selectivity. The role of Cs is to disperse the active phase and form stable heteropolyacids. The co doping of metals in the primary and secondary structures can achieve different catalytic effects and jointly change the selectivity of MAA. 4 Conclusion The research in this paper focuses on the utilization of isobutylene and addresses the issue of overcapacity. A composite catalyst, Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV, was successfully developed for the one-step oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid. This catalyst combines asymmetric lattice oxygen with a moderately acidic modified heteropolyacid catalyst. The optimal catalytic ratio of Mo-V-P-Ce to KCsWPAV was found to be 1:1. By optimizing the Ce content in the Mo-V-P metal oxide catalyst, the best methacrylic acid selectivity was achieved with a material ratio of Mo: V: P: Ce = 7:3:0.3:0.075. The addition of Ce enhances the oxidation ability of active Mo species and promotes oxygen activation to enhance methacrylic acid oxidation. Characterization results suggest that the active center for oxidized methacrylic acid is Mo6+-O-V5+, while for oxidized MAL, it is the acidic proton on the terminal or bridging oxygen of the Keggin unit. The modification of heteropolyacid increases moderately acidic sites, improving methacrylic acid selectivity. Under optimal conditions (atmosphere: isobutylene molar feed ratio ≥25:1, temperature 400 °C), the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst achieved up to 91 % isobutylene conversion with 70 % methacrylic acid selectivity, while producing MAL and carbon oxides as by-products. coredata.dc:description: The direct synthesis of methyl methacrylate from isobutene is of great importance in the chemical industry. The direct oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid is one of the key steps, but the selectivity of methacrylic acid is low in the products of one-step oxidation of isobutylene. The efficient one-step oxidation of isobutylene to methacrylic acid was achieved by preparing a Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV two-component composite catalyst combining asymmetric lattice oxygen with appropriate acidic heteropolyacid catalysts. The catalyst was characterized using XRD, FT-IR, BET, SEM, and others to analyze its structural properties, dimensional characteristics, and more. Results indicated that the composite catalyst accelerated the crystallization rate, with Ce enhancing the oxidation of the active molybdenum species and promoting oxygen activation to form lattice oxygen, thereby improving the oxidation of isobutylene. The heteropoly acids increased the percentage of medium strong acidic sites, enhancing the selectivity of methacrylic acid. Under optimized conditions, with an atmosphere to isobutylene molar feed ratio of ≥25:1 and a temperature of 400 °C, the Mo-V-P-Ce/KCsWPAV catalyst achieved a remarkable 91 % conversion of isobutylene with a 70 % selectivity towards methacrylic acid. The catalyst shows promise for practical applications in the one-step oxidation of isobutylene to produce methacrylic acid, providing a suitable solution to the problem of isobutylene overcapacity.
